title: fanoutqa: What are the five highest grossing films of all time as of November 2023 (not adjusting for inflation), and who directed each film? (ffb482fefde57323)

</fragment>
<fragment>

While inflation has eroded the achievements of most films from the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, there are franchises originating from that period that are still active. Besides the *Star Wars* and *Superman* franchises, *James Bond* and *Godzilla* films are still being released periodically; all four are among the highest-grossing franchises. Some of the older films that held the record of highest-grossing film still have respectable grosses by today's standards, but no longer compete numerically against today's top-earners in an era of much higher individual ticket prices. When those prices are adjusted for inflation, however, then *Gone with the Wind*—which was the highest-grossing film outright for twenty-five years—is still the highest-grossing film of all time. All grosses on the list are expressed in U.S. dollars at their nominal value, except where stated otherwise.

<fragment>

On this chart, films are ranked by the revenues from theatrical exhibition at their nominal value, along with the highest positions they attained. Six films in total have grossed in excess of $2 billion worldwide, with *Avatar* ranked in the top position. All of the films have had a theatrical run (including re-releases) in the 21st century, and films that have not played during this period do not appear on the chart because of ticket-price inflation, population size and ticket purchasing trends not being considered.




† *Background shading indicates films playing in the week commencing 13 June 2024 in theaters around the world*.

T*Guinness*' adjusted total for *Titanic* only increased by $102,000,000 between the 2012 (published in 2011) and 2015 editions, a rise of 4.2% shared by the other adjusted totals in the chart, and omitted the gross from a 3D re-release in 2012.[35][38] This chart incorporates the gross of $343,550,770 from the reissue and adjusts it from the 2013 index.[39] *Titanic* grossed a further $762,994 during limited re-releases in 2017 and 2020, but this sum is not represented in the adjusted total.[40]


AEThe gross for *Avengers: Endgame* is adjusted from the 2020 index.


TFAThe gross for *Star Wars: The Force Awakens* is adjusted from the 2016 index.

<fragment>
At least eleven films have held the record of 'highest-grossing film' since *The Birth of a Nation* assumed the top spot in 1915. Both *The Birth of a Nation* and *Gone with the Wind* spent twenty-five consecutive years apiece as the highest-grosser, with films directed by Steven Spielberg and James Cameron holding the record on three occasions each. Spielberg became the first director to break his own record when *Jurassic Park* overtook *E.T.*, and Cameron emulated the feat when *Avatar* broke the record set by *Titanic*. When it took over the top spot in 2019, *Avengers: Endgame* became the first sequel to hold the record of highest-grossing film, and in doing so interrupted thirty-six years of Spielberg/Cameron dominance before *Avatar* reclaimed the top spot two years later in 2021 upon a re-release.

Despite the inherent difficulties in accounting for inflation, several attempts have been made. Estimates depend on the price index used to adjust the grosses,[31] and the exchange rates used to convert between currencies can also affect the calculations, both of which can have an effect on the ultimate rankings of an inflation adjusted list. *Gone with the Wind*—first released in 1939—is generally considered to be the most successful film, with *Guinness World Records* in 2014 estimating its adjusted global gross at $3.4 billion.

<fragment>
*Avengers: Endgame* grossed $858.4 million in the United States and Canada, and $1.941 billion in other territories, for a worldwide total of $2.799 billion,[4] becoming the highest-grossing film of all time[148] (until it was surpassed by *Avatar* (2009) due to the 2021 re-release in China[149]), as well as the second-highest-grossing film of all time in the United States and Canada.[150] Adjusted for inflation, *Gone with the Wind* (1939) remains the highest-grossing film, and *Avengers: Endgame* is the fifth-highest-grossing film of all time worldwide.[151]


</fragment>
<fragment>
147. **^** Byford, Sam (November 8, 2021). "Disney Plus Is Upgrading Marvel Movies to IMAX Aspect Ratio". *The Verge*. Archived from the original on November 8, 2021. Retrieved November 8, 2021.
148. **^** McClintock, Pamela (July 20, 2019). "Box Office: *Avengers: Endgame* Passes *Avatar* to Become No. 1 Film of All Time". *The Hollywood Reporter*. Archived from the original on July 21, 2019. Retrieved July 21, 2019.
149. **^** Tartaglione, Nancy (March 13, 2021). "*Avatar* Overtakes *Avengers: Endgame* as All-Time Highest-Grossing Film Worldwide; Rises to $2.8B Amid China Reissue – Update". *Deadline Hollywood*. Archived from the original on March 13, 2021. Retrieved March 13, 2021.
150. **^** "All Time Domestic Box Office". *The Numbers*. Archived from the original on June 14, 2021. Retrieved June 14, 2021.

</fragment>
<fragment>

The film had a worldwide opening of $1.2 billion, the biggest of all time and nearly double *Infinity War*'s previous record of $640 million.[152] It is also the fastest film ever to eclipse the $1 billion and $1.5 billion mark, doing so in just five days and eight days, respectively.[153] *Deadline Hollywood* estimated the film would break even just five days after its release, which is "unheard of for a major studio tentpole during its opening weekend".[2] The website eventually calculated the film's final net profit as $890 million, accounting for production budgets, marketing, talent participations, and other costs; box office grosses and home media revenues placed it first on their list of 2019's "Most Valuable Blockbusters".[154]


</fragment>
<fragment>

![](image)Chart of the North American box office gross of *Avengers: Endgame* against the four highest-grossing films in the market

</fragment>
</document>
chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
<document>
<title>Avatar: The Way of Water</title>
<fragment>

Outside the US and Canada, the film grossed $307.6 million in 52 countries in its first week of release. The largest openings for the film by the end of the week were in China ($56.8 million), South Korea ($24.9 million), France ($21.7 million), Germany ($19.4 million) and India ($19.2 million).[211][212] In the second weekend, it grossed $168.6 million for a drop of 42%.[241] In the third weekend, it grossed $186.7 million, an increase of 6% from the previous weekend.[242] In the fourth weekend, it grossed $132.6 million for a drop of 30%, while becoming the highest-grossing film of the pandemic era outside the US and Canada.[243] The five largest-running total countries by February 26, 2023, are China ($249.8 million), France ($148.3 million), Germany ($138.3 million), South Korea ($105 million) and the United Kingdom ($91 million). It became the highest-grossing film of all time in twenty box office territories, including Germany, France, Austria, Turkey and New Zealand.[244][245][246][247]




</fragment>
<fragment>
243. **^** Tartaglione, Nancy (January 8, 2023). "'Avatar: The Way Of Water' Flies Past $1.7B Global, Now 7th Biggest Movie Ever; 'Puss In Boots' Nears $200M WW – International Box Office". *Deadline Hollywood*. Archived from the original on January 8, 2023. Retrieved January 8, 2023.
244. **^** Gant, Charles (February 20, 2023). "'Ant-Man 3' soars with $225m global box office debut; 'Avatar 2' overtakes 'Titanic' in all-time ranking". Screen Daily. Archived from the original on February 21, 2023. Retrieved February 20, 2023.
245. **^** "'Avatar: The Way of Water' Is the 4th Highest-Grossing Film of All-Time". *The Walt Disney Company*. January 30, 2023. Archived from the original on February 7, 2023. Retrieved February 1, 2023.
246. **^** Jamie Lovett (January 29, 2023). "Avatar: The Way of Water Passes Star Wars: The Force Awakens to Become Fourth Highest Grossing Movie of All Time". *ComicBook.com*. ViacomCBS. Archived from the original on February 6, 2023. Retrieved February 1, 2023.

</fragment>

216. **^** McClintock, Pamela (December 28, 2022). "Box Office Milestone: 'Avatar 2' Crosses $1B Globally in 14 Days". *The Hollywood Reporter*. Archived from the original on December 28, 2022. Retrieved December 28, 2022.
217. **^** "Avatar The Way of Water box office: James Cameron movie crosses $1 billion in 14 days; 6th fastest film ever to do so". *Hindustan Times*. December 28, 2022. Archived from the original on December 29, 2022. Retrieved December 29, 2022.

</fragment>
<fragment>

It is the fourth film to reach the $1 billion milestone in the pandemic era after *Spider-Man: No Way Home*, *Top Gun: Maverick* and *Jurassic World Dominion*, as well as the sixth-fastest overall to reach the milestone at 14 days.[216][217] It crossed the $2 billion milestone on January 22, becoming the first film in the pandemic era and the sixth in history to reach the milestone. It is also the second-fastest to gross over $2 billion, reaching the milestone in 40 days.[218][219] *Deadline Hollywood* calculated the film's net profit as $531.7 million, accounting for production budgets, marketing, talent participations and other costs; box office grosses and home media revenues placed it first on their list of 2022's "Most Valuable Blockbusters".[220]



#### United States and Canada[edit]


</fragment>
</document>

<fragment>

Including revenue from the 2012, 2017 and 2023 reissues, *Titanic* earned $674.3 million in North America and $1.583 billion in other countries, for a worldwide total of $2.257 billion.[Note 1][14] It became the highest-grossing film of all time worldwide in 1998, beating *Jurassic Park* (1993).[105] The film remained so for twelve years, until *Avatar* (2009), also written and directed by Cameron, surpassed it in 2010.[106] On March 1, 1998,[107] it became the first film to earn more than $1 billion worldwide[108] and on the weekend April 13–15, 2012—a century after the original vessel's foundering, *Titanic* became the second film to cross the $2 billion threshold during its 3D re-release.[109] Box Office Mojo estimates that *Titanic* is the fifth-highest-grossing film of all time in North America when adjusting for ticket price inflation.[110] The site also estimates that the film sold over 128 million tickets in the US in its initial theatrical run.[111]

*Star Wars: The Force Awakens* grossed $936.7 million in the United States and Canada and $1.132 billion in other countries for a worldwide total of $2.068 billion,[3] making it the highest-grossing film of 2015[280] and the third highest-grossing film of all time.[281] Box Office Mojo estimates that the film sold close to 110 million tickets in the United States and Canada.[282] *The Force Awakens* earned 8.6% of the total 2015 releases in the United States and Canada, second only to the 8.8% of the box office earned by *Titanic* in 1997.[283] It was the 24th film in cinematic history to gross $1 billion worldwide, standing as the fastest film to surpass the mark at the time, doing so in 12 days.[284] It was also the third film in history to surpass $2 billion worldwide, doing so on its 53rd day of release.[285] *Deadline Hollywood* calculated the film's net profit as $780.1 million, accounting for production budgets, marketing, talent participations, 
</fragment>
<fragment>

282. **^** "Domestic Grosses Adjusted for Ticket Price Inflation". Box Office Mojo. Archived from the original on December 20, 2016. Retrieved July 12, 2016.
283. **^** Mendelson, Scott (March 11, 2016). "Hollywood Is Doomed Because 'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' Made Too Much Money?". *Forbes*. Archived from the original on March 14, 2016. Retrieved March 11, 2016.
284. **^** Lang, Brent (December 27, 2015). "Box Office: 'Star Wars' Crosses $1 Billion Globally at Record Pace". *Variety*. Archived from the original on December 27, 2015. Retrieved December 27, 2015.
285. **^** D'Alessandro, Anthony (February 5, 2016). "'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' Reaches Unprecedented Height At Domestic B.O. With $900M, $2B Worldwide". *Deadline Hollywood*. Archived from the original on February 6, 2016. Retrieved February 7, 2016.

chat_history.name: search

chat_history.content:
Here are some key details about the highest-grossing films:

### Avatar (2009)
- **Director**: James Cameron
- **Box Office**: Over $2.8 billion worldwide
- **Notable Achievements**: 
  - Fastest film to break the $1 billion mark.
  - Became the highest-grossing film of all time until it was surpassed by "Avengers: Endgame" and later reclaimed the title after a re-release in China.

### Avengers: Endgame (2019)
- **Directors**: Anthony and Joe Russo
- **Box Office**: $2.799 billion worldwide
- **Notable Achievements**: 
  - Highest-grossing film of all time until "Avatar" reclaimed the title.
  - Fastest film to reach $1 billion and $1.5 billion, doing so in just five and eight days, respectively.

### Avatar: The Way of Water (2022)
- **Director**: James Cameron
- **Box Office**: Over $2 billion worldwide
- **Notable Achievements**: 
  - Became the highest-grossing film of the pandemic era outside the US and Canada.
  - Fastest film to gross over $2 billion in the pandemic era.

### Titanic (1997)
- **Director**: James Cameron
- **Box Office**: $2.257 billion worldwide (including reissues)
- **Notable Achievements**: 
  - First film to earn more than $1 billion worldwide.
  - Held the title of highest-grossing film of all time for 12 years until "Avatar" surpassed it.

### Star Wars: The Force Awakens (2015)
- **Director**: J.J. Abrams
- **Box Office**: $2.068 billion worldwide
- **Notable Achievements**: 
  - Highest-grossing film of 2015.
  - Fastest film to surpass $1 billion worldwide at the time, doing so in 12 days.

These films have set numerous records and have had significant impacts on the film industry, both in terms of box office performance and cultural influence.

functions.name: search
functions.desc: Search Wikipedia for an article with the given title, and get its content. If no such article is found, return similar article names.
